awd_titl_txt: The Navajo Technical University Pathways to STEM Careers Project
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project aligns directly with that goal, and moreover will inform the body of knowledge about the importance and conduct of pre-college and undergraduate research and educational experiences in recruiting and retaining underrepresented individuals into STEM studies, and preparing the next generation of STEM professionals. The connection of faculty to research and thereby the students to culturally and locally relevant research is an important step in graduating students who are more likely to pursue advanced degrees. For those students entering the workforce directly from a tribal college it is equally important that they have a well-defined skill set in mathematics, science, and technology for entry into the STEM workforce. 

The Navajo Technical University Pathways to STEM Careers Project is designed to strengthen the university's E-Learning capabilities by:  providing resources to deliver such instruction; developing a pre-engineering certificate and curriculum designed for such instruction, to enable American Indian students from remote areas and high schools in New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado to pursue engineering studies; providing an academic ladder to an engineering degree for those students; and researching the effectiveness of E-Learning with Navajo, Pueblo, and Ute students.  The project also provides resources to engage engineering students at Navajo Technical University, working with professional support, with students working toward the pre-engineering certificate.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
One of the primary intellectual merits of the project is the development and implementation of innovative curriculum models for engineering education. Through student and community input, rigorous research and experimentation, the project team has refined demanding introductory engineering certificate curricula that leverage e-learning resources and experiential learning methodologies. These curricula serve as models for STEM curriculum delivery at Navajo Tech and other Tribal Colleges and Universities (TCUs) nationally, that we present at conferences nationally and at TCU conferences, we regularly disseminate resources and help other TCUs to start their engineer programs. The project has successfully developed dual credit models that increase enrollment in academically rigorous post-secondary STEM programs among students from Navajo, Pueblo, and Ute serving high schools. By addressing the intellectual merit of curriculum development and program design, the project has made significant contributions to the field of engineering education.

In terms of broader impacts, the Pathways Project has had far-reaching effects on human resources development and societal engagement. The project has significantly increased the number of Southwest American Indian students enrolling in engineering baccalaureate degree programs at Navajo Tech and other colleges and universities. This expansion of access to higher education opportunities enhances the human capital within Indigenous communities and strengthens the engineering workforce with diverse perspectives and talents. Moreover, the project's focus on integrating Indigenous Ways of Knowing and traditional knowledge into engineering education has profound societal implications. By honoring and valuing Indigenous perspectives on science and technology, the project fosters cultural preservation and revitalization while also promoting greater diversity and inclusion in STEM fields. These broader impacts extend beyond the academic realm to contribute to social equity, economic empowerment, and cultural resilience within Indigenous communities.

The outcomes of the Navajo Tech Pathways Project highlights its intellectual merit and broader impacts on STEM education, Indigenous communities, and society at large. Through innovative and indigenous integration in curriculum development, increased access to higher education, and the integration of Indigenous knowledge systems, the project has advanced knowledge in the field of engineering education while also promoting cultural preservation and social justice. As a result, the project represents a significant contribution to both the academic community and the broader society, aligning with the goals and objectives of the NSF merit review criteria.

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Peter Romine
